title: On the number of n-ary quasigroups of finite order

title_detail.value: On the number of n-ary quasigroups of finite order

summary:
Let $Q(n,k)$ be the number of $n$-ary quasigroups of order $k$. We derive a
recurrent formula for Q(n,4). We prove that for all $n\geq 2$ and $k\geq 5$ the
following inequalities hold: $({k-3}/2)^{n/2}(\frac{k-1}2)^{n/2} < log_2 Q(n,k)
\leq {c_k(k-2)^{n}} $, where $c_k$ does not depend on $n$. So, the upper
asymptotic bound for $Q(n,k)$ is improved for any $k\geq 5$ and the lower bound
is improved for odd $k\geq 7$. Keywords: n-ary quasigroup, latin cube, loop,
asymptotic estimate, component, latin trade.

1. Introduction
An algebraic system from a set Σ of cardinality |Σ| = k and n-ary operation f : Σn → Σ
is called an n-ary quasigroup of order k iff the unary operation obtained by fixing any n − 1
arguments of f by any values from Σ is always bijective. The corresponding function f is often
also called an n-ary quasigroup (the value table of such a function is known as latin hypercube;
if n = 2, latin square).
Let us fix the set Σ = {0, 1, . . . , k − 1}. Denote by Q(n, k) the number of different n-ary
quasigroups of order k (for fixed Σ)1 . It is known that for every n there exist only two n-ary
quasigroups of order 2. There are exactly Q(n, 3) = 3 * 2n different n-ary quasigroups of order
n
3, which form one equivalence class. In [9] it is proved that Q(n, 4) = 3n+1 22 +1 (1 + o(1)) as
n → ∞. In Section 4 we suggest a recurrent way to calculate the numbers Q(n, 4) and list the
first 8 values. Before, only five values of Q(n, 4) where known; furthermore the numbers Q(n, 5)
and Q(n, 6) are known for n ≤ 5 and n ≤ 3 respectively, see [7], and the number Q(2, k) for
k ≤ 11, see [6] and references there.
The asymptotics of the number and even of the logarithm of the number (and even of
the logarithm of the logarithm of the number) of n-ary quasigroups of orders more than 4 is
n/3

2. An upper bound
We will say that a set M ⊆ Σn satisfies Property (A) iff for every element x̄ ∈ M and every
position i = 1, . . . , n there is another element ȳ ∈ M differing from x̄ only in the position i. By
induction it is easy to get the following:
Proposition 1. Any nonempty subset C ⊆ Σn that satisfies Property (A) has the cardinality
at least 2n .
A function g : Ω → Σ where Ω ⊂ Σn is called a partial n-ary quasigroup of order |Σ| if
g(x) 6= g(y) for any two tuples x, y ∈ Ω differing in exactly one position. We will say that an
n-ary quasigroup f : Σn → Σ is an extension of a partial n-ary quasigroup g : Ω → Σ where
Ω ⊂ Σn if f |Ω ≡ g.
Lemma 1. Let |Σ| = k, B = Σ \ {a, b}, k ≥ 3, a, b ∈ Σ. Then a partial n-ary quasigroup
n−1

different extensions.

Proof. Denote by P the set of the unordered pairs of elements of Σ. Consider a partial
n-ary quasigroup g : Σn−1 × B → Σ. Define the function G : Σn−1 → P by the equality
G(x) = Σ \ {g(xc) : c ∈ Σ \ {a, b}}. Define the graph Γ = hΣn−1 , Ei where two vertices x and y
are adjacent if and only if the tuples x and y differ in exactly one position and G(x) ∩ G(y) 6= ∅.
It is easy to see that connected components of Γ satisfy Property (A).
Let n-ary quasigroups f1 and f2 be extensions of g. It is not difficult to see that {f1 (xa), f1 (xb)} =
G(x) for every x ∈ Σn−1 ; moreover, if f1 (xa) = f2 (xa), then f1 and f2 coincide on the whole
connected component of Γ containing x ∈ Σn−1 . So, to define an extension of g uniquely it is
sufficient to choose one from the two possible values for every connected component of Γ. It
follows from Proposition 1 that every connected component has cardinality at least 2n−1 . Then
the number of connected components of Γ does dot exceed (k/2)n−1 . Hence g has not more than

Let a and b be two different elements of Σ. By {a, b}-component of an n-ary quasigroupf
we will mean such a set S ⊂ Σn that 1) f (S) = {a, b} and 2) the function

is also an n-ary quasigroup. In this case we will say that g is obtained from f by switching
the component S. We note that in the definition of an {a, b}-component the condition 2) can
be replaced by Property (A) from the previous section. It is obvious that switching disjoint
components can be performed independently:
Proposition 2. Let S and S 0 be disjoint {a, b}- and {c, d}- (respectively) components of an
n-ary quasigroup f . Let an n-ary quasigroup g is obtained from f by switching S. Then S 0 is
a {c, d}-component of g too.
The following proposition can be easily derived from the definition of an {a, b}-component;
similar statement can be found in [5].

Proposition 3. Let C = {c1 , d1 } × {c2 , d2 } be an {a, b}-component of a 2-ary quasigroup g.
Let Ci be a {ci , di }-component of an ni -ary quasigroup qi , i = 1, 2. Then the set C1 × C2 is an
{a, b}-component of the (n1 + n2 )-ary quasigroup f , where f (x̄1 , x̄2 ) ≡ g(q1 (x̄1 ), q2 (x̄2 )).

A 2-ary quasigroup φ : Σ → Σ is called idempotent iff φ(x, x) = x for every x ∈ Σ. It is
known (see, e.g., [1]) that
Proposition 4. For every m ≥ 3 there exists an idempotent 2-ary quasigroup of order m.

The following proposition presents a construction of 2-ary quasigroups, which will be used
to establish a lower bound on the number of n-ary quasigroups of odd order.

Proposition 5. For any m ≥ 3 there exists a 2-ary quasigroup ψ of order 2m + 1 that has m
{2i, 2i + 1}-components for every i ∈ {0, . . . , m − 1}; moreover, all except one {2i, 2i + 1}-components have form {2j, 2j + 1} × {2l, 2l + 1}.

Proof. By Proposition 4 there exists an idempotent 2-ary quasigroup φm of order m. For
each a, b ∈ {0, . . . , m − 1}, a 6= b, and δ, σ ∈ {0, 1} define
ψ(2a + δ, 2b + σ) = 2φm (a, b) + (δ + σ mod 2);
ψ(2a + δ, 2a + δ) = 2a + 1 − δ;
ψ(2a + δ, 2a + 1 − δ) = k − 1;
ψ(k − 1, 2a + δ) = ψ(2a + δ, k − 1) = 2a + δ;
ψ(k − 1, k − 1) = k − 1.
Straightforwardly, ψ is a 2-ary quasigroup that satisfied the desired properties. N

4. The number of different n-ary quasigroups of order 4
Denote [n] = {1, . . . , n}. An n-ary quasigroup f is called an n-ary loop iff there exists
an element e ∈ Σ, which is called an identity, such that for all i ∈ [n] and a ∈ Σ it is true
f (e . . . eae . . . e) = a. In what follows we always assume that 0 is an identity of an n-ary loop (in
i

general, an n-ary loop can have more than one identities provided n ≥ 3). Especially we note
that this agreement is essential in the treatment of the concept of the number of n-ary loops.
In particular, we have the following simple and well-known fact:
Proposition 6. Let Q0 (n, k) be the number of n-ary loops of order k. Then
Q(n, k) = k * ((k − 1)!)n Q0 (n, k).
An n-ary quasigroop f is called permutably reducible (we will omit "permutably") iff there
exist an integer m, 2 ≤ m < n, an (n − m + 1)-ary quasigroup h, an m-ary quasigroup g ,
and a permutation σ : [n] → [n] such that

f (x1 , . . . , xn ) ≡ h g(xσ(1) , . . . , xσ(m) ), xσ(m+1) , . . . , xσ(n) .
In this section we will assume that Σ = {0, 1, 2, 3}; i.e., we will consider only the n-ary
quasigroups of order 4. It is known (see, e.g., [1]) that there are exactly four binary loops of
order 4 (one is isomorphic to the group Z2 × Z2 and three, to the group Z4 ).

5. Conclusion
We will briefly discuss a connection of our topic with the known concept of latin traid. A
partial n-ary quasigroup t : Ω → Σ, Ω ⊂ Σn is called a multidimensional latin trade, here for
briefity simply trade iff there exist another partial n-ary quasigroup t0 : Ω → Σ such that
1) t(x̄) 6= t0 (x̄) for all x̄ ∈ Ω;
2) for any i from 1 to n and any admissible values x1 , . . . , xi−1 , xi−1 , . . . , xn the sets
{t(x1 , . . . , xi−1 , y, xi−1 , . . . , xn ) | y ∈ Σ} and {t0 (x1 , . . . , xi−1 , y, xi−1 , . . . , xn ) | y ∈ Σ} coincide.
In this case the pair (t, t0 ) is called a bitrade (depending on the context, bitrades are considered either as ordered, or as unordered pairs); the trade t0 is called a mate of t. In the case
n = 2 bitrades (latin bitrades) are widely studied, see the survey [2].
We will say that an n-ary quasigroup f has a trade t iff t = f |Ω for some Ω. As follows
from the definitions, replacing of the values of f in Ω by the values of a mate t0 of t results in
another n-ary quasigroup. We will say that trades t = f |Ω and s = f |Θ are independent iff their
supports Ω and Θ are disjoint. The maximal number of mutually independent trades of an n-ary
quasigroup f will be called its trade number trd(f ). Denote by Trd(n, k) the maximum of trd(f )
over the all n-ary quasigroups f of order k. Since independent trades of an n-ary quasigroup
can be independently replaced by mates, the number Q(n, k) of different n-ary quasigroups of
order k satisfies
Q(n, k) ≥ 2Trd(n,k) .
(6)
It is easy to understand that the lower bound in Section 3 (as well as all the bounds in [5]) is
derived by this way: {a, b}-component is the support of some trade by definitions. Since the
support of a trade satisfies Property (A), Proposition 1 implies Trd(n, k) ≤ k n /2n = 2(log2 k−1)n ;
moreover, for even k the equality is easily proved. For odd k, as follows from the results of
Section 3, we have Trd(n, k) ≥ 2c(k)n where c(k) −→ log2 k − 1. But for fixed k, in particular,
k→∞

Problem 1. Establish the asymptotics of the logarithm and the asymptotics of the value
Trd(n, k) as n → ∞ for odd k ≥ 5.

Another question is how the estimation (6) close to the real value. For the order 4 it is

is unknown. It is natural to conjecture that the asymptotics of log log Q(n, k) and log Trd(n, k)
coincide.

if n+j>0: P[n+sum(Po.values())+j]+=[Pn]

for Pn in P: Pn.pop()

\# remove trivial 1-partitions

from math import factorial
mul = lambda a,b:a*b
Aut = lambda Pt:reduce(mul,[factorial(Pt[nu])*factorial(nu)**Pt[nu] for nu in Pt], 1)
F=[[factorial(n)/Aut(Pt) for Pt in P[n]] for n in range(N+1)]
\# F[n][i] is the number of partitions of an n-set

La=[2L**(2**n-n-1) for n in range(N+1)]

for i in range(len(P[n])):
R_0[n], Ra0[n], R_s[n], Ras[n] = map(lambda A, B, C :
A[n] + reduce(mul,[(B[nu]-C*A[nu])**P[n][i][nu] for nu in P[n][i]],1)
*((1-C)*P_a[sum(P[n][i].values())]+C)*F[n][i],
(R_0, Ra0, R_s, Ras), (V, La, V, La), (0, 0, 1, 1))
R_0[n] *= 3
P_a[n] = La[n] - Ra0[n] - 2*Ras[n]
V[n] = 3*P_a[n] + R_0[n] + 4*R_s[n]
T[n] = 4*(6**n)*V[n]

1. Введение
Алгебраическая система из множества Σ мощности |Σ| = k и n-арной операции
f : Σn → Σ называется n-арной квазигруппой порядка k, если унарная операция, полученная фиксацией любых n − 1 аргументов операции f любыми значениями из Σ, всегда
является биекцией. Принято называть n-арной квазигруппой порядка k или n-квазигруппой
порядка k также и соответствующую функцию f (таблица значений такой функции известна
под названием латинский гиперкуб, в случае n = 2 - латинский квадрат).
Зафиксируем множество элементов Σ = {0, 1, . . . , k − 1}. Обозначим через Q(n, k) число
различных n-арных квазигрупп порядка k (при фиксированном Σ)1 . Известно, что для
каждого n существует только две n-арных квазигруппы порядка 2. Имеется Q(n, 3) = 3 *
2n различных n-арных квазигрупп порядка 3, которые составляют единственный класс
n
эквивалентности. В [1] доказано асимптотическое равенство Q(n, 4) = 3n+1 22 +1 (1 + o(1))
при n → ∞. В настоящей работе (раздел 4) предложен рекуррентный способ вычисления
чисел Q(n, 4), выписаны первые 8 значений этой величины. Ранее были известны только
пять первых значений Q(n, 4), кроме того, известны числа Q(n, 5) и Q(n, 6) для n ≤ 5 и
n ≤ 3 соответственно, см. [9], и число Q(2, k) при k ≤ 11, см. работу [8] и библиографию в
ней.

5. Заключение
В заключении скажем несколько слов о связи тематики настоящей статьи с известным понятием латинского трэйда (latin trade). Частичная n-арная квазигруппа t : Ω → Σ,
Ω ⊂ Σn называется многомерным латинским трэйдом, далее просто трэйдом, если существует другая частичная n-арная квазигруппа t′ : Ω → Σ такая, что
1) t( ̄
x) ̸= t′ ( ̄
x) для всех x
 ̄ ∈ Ω;
2) для любого i, i = 1, . . . , n, и для любых допустимых значений x1 , . . . , xi−1 , xi−1 , . . . , xn
множества {t(x1 , . . . , xi−1 , y, xi−1 , . . . , xn ) | y ∈ Σ} и {t′ (x1 , . . . , xi−1 , y, xi−1 , . . . , xn ) | y ∈ Σ}
совпадают.
В этом случае пара (t, t′ ) называется битрейдом (в зависимости от контекста, битрейд
рассматривают как упорядоченную, либо как неупорядоченную пару), а трэйд t′ называется партнёром трэйда t. Исследованию битрэйдов в случае n = 2 (латинских битрэйдов)
уделяется значительное внимание, см. обзор [5].
Будем говорить, что n-арная квазигруппа f содержит трэйд t, если t = f |Ω для некоторого Ω. При этом из определений следует, что замена значений f на множестве Ω значениями партнёра t′ трэйда t приводит к другой n-арной квазигруппе. Трэйды t = f |Ω и
s = f |Θ назовём независимыми, если их носители (области определения) Ω и Θ не пересекаются. Максимальное число попарно независимых трэйдов, которые содержит n-арная
квазигруппа f , назовём её трэйдовым числом trd(f ). Максимум trd(f ) по всем n-арным
квазигруппам f порядка k обозначим через Trd(n, k). Поскольку независимые трэйды в
n-арной квазигруппе можно независимо заменять на партнёров, число Q(n, k) различных
n-арных квазигрупп порядка k удовлетворяет неравенству
Q(n, k) ≥ 2Trd(n,k) .

(6)

Легко понять, что нижняя оценка в разделе 3 (как и все оценки в [7]) получена именно
таким образом: {a, b}-компонента по определению является носителем некоторого трэйда.
Поскольку носитель трэйда обладает свойством (A), из предложения 1 вытекает Trd(n, k) ≤
k n /2n = 2(log2 k−1)n , причем для чётных k легко доказать равенство. Для нечётных k из
результатов раздела 3 следует оценка Trd(n, k) ≥ 2c(k)n , где c(k) −→ log2 k − 1. Однако для
k→∞

фиксированных k, в частности, для малых значений 5, 7, . . . вопрос об асимптотическом
поведении величины Trd(n, k) остаётся открытым.

N=12 \# the maximum arity to calculate
P=[[{}]]+[[] for x in [0]*N]

for Po in P[n]:

Pn={i+1:Po[i] for i in Po}
if j>0: Pn.update({1:j})
if n+j>0: P[n+sum(Po.values())+j]+=[Pn]
\# now P[n] is a list of partitions of n into positive summands:
\# E.g., 16==1*3+2*4+5*1==(1+1+1)+(2+2+2+2)+(5) is saved as P[16][51]=={1:3, 2:4, 5:1}
for Pn in P: Pn.pop()

\# remove trivial 1-partitions

from math import factorial
mul = lambda a,b:a*b
Aut = lambda Pt:reduce(mul,[factorial(Pt[nu])*factorial(nu)**Pt[nu] for nu in Pt], 1)
F=[[factorial(n)/Aut(Pt) for Pt in P[n]] for n in range(N+1)]
\# F[n][i] is the number of partitions of an n-set
\# that correspond to the partition P[n][i] of n.
La=[2L**(2**n-n-1) for n in range(N+1)]
Ras,Ra0,R_0,R_s,P_a,V,T = [0,0L],[0, 0L],[0,0L],[0,0L],[0,0L],[1,1L],[4,24L]
for n in range(2, N+1):
V+=[0L]; T+=[0L]; P_a+=[0L]; Ras+=[0L]; Ra0+=[0L]; R_0+=[0L]; R_s+=[0L]
for i in range(len(P[n])):

A[n] + reduce(mul,[(B[nu]-C*A[nu])**P[n][i][nu] for nu in P[n][i]],1)
*((1-C)*P_a[sum(P[n][i].values())]+C)*F[n][i],
(R_0, Ra0, R_s, Ras), (V, La, V, La), (0, 0, 1, 1))
R_0[n] *= 3
P_a[n] = La[n] - Ra0[n] - 2*Ras[n]
V[n] = 3*P_a[n] + R_0[n] + 4*R_s[n]
T[n] = 4*(6**n)*V[n]
